This report was prepared by KyeongAe Choe, Agriculture, Environment, and Natural Resources

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  Programming  Mission  in  2002,  the 
Government of Uzbekistan requested advisory technical assistance (TA) to improve its cadastre 
and real property registration system. The Government considers that a unified state cadastre 
system would lead to more efficient use of land resources and real property, and ease the 
transition to a market economy. A concept note to this effect was submitted to ADB by the State 
Committee for Land Resources in September 2002 and the TA1 was later included in the 2003 
Program in ADB’s Country Strategy and Program Update (2003–2005). A Fact-Finding Mission 
fielded by ADB in May 2003 held discussions based on the concept note with staffs of central and 
local government agencies and international agencies concerned, and reached an understanding 
with  the  Government  on  the  objectives,  scope,  cost  estimates,  terms  of  reference,  and 
implementation arrangements for the TA. The TA framework is presented in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Agriculture is the foundation of the Uzbek economy. It accounts for about 28% of the 
gross domestic product (GDP) and employs about 44% of the labor force. Cotton exports alone 
bring in almost 50% of foreign exchange earnings. However, serious environmental problems 
following decades of rigid state control over agricultural activities have led to a decline in cotton 
and wheat production and substantial financial losses for state-controlled cooperative farms. 
Mandatory production targets severely restrict crop rotation and push farmers to overuse water, 
fertilizers, and chemicals. Thus, water resources are depleted and soil quality impaired. The 
incentive to improve agricultural productivity remains an issue as the entire production is sold to 
the State at a regulated price.   
 
3.  To improve productivity, the Government has made it a policy to restructure state farms 
gradually  as  part  of  the  transition  toward  a  market  economy.  Restructuring  involves  (i) 
reorganizing cooperative farms and distributing the lands to individual farmers; (ii) adopting more 
flexible cropping patterns and significantly lower procurement quotas for cotton and wheat; and 
(iii) giving farmers the freedom to sell yields produced above the quota. Changes in agricultural 
policy2 and land tenure have allowed private farmers to hold private use rights and to decide on 
their own what to grow and what to sell in the market above certain reduced quotas for cotton and 
wheat to be sold at fixed prices to the government. In the last 2 years, more than 300 cooperative 
farms (about 15% of the national total) were reorganized, and more than 1.66 million hectares of 
land was distributed to more than 80,000 individual farmers. The increasing productivity of these 
farms has encouraged the Government to continue the restructuring (Presidential Decree on 24 
March 2003). 
 
4.  As the Government is committed to privatize more farmland, individual land parcels must 
be marked out, registered, and accurately graded. There is, thus, an urgent need to strengthen 
the cadastre system so as to (i) accurately assess and collect the land tax, (ii) privatize farms on 
the basis of sound technical principles, (iii) ensure sustainable management of land resources, 
and  (iv)  facilitate  the  eventual  adoption  of  private  property  rights  and  secure  land  tenure.3 
                                                 
1
 The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (Internet version) on 21 April 2003. 
2
 ADB. 2001. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan and 
Technical Assistance Grant to the Republic of Uzbekistan for the Ak Altin Agricultural Development Project. Manila. 
3
 The legal status of asset ownership  and responsibilities for maintenance  are  unclear, causing  confusion  on 
individualized farming operation. According to the 1998 Land Code of Uzbekistan, land leased for possession or use 
can only be transferred through inheritance up to the expiration of the term established in the original lease contract. 
The code does not address the issue of private land ownership and assumes that all land will remain State-owned for 
the foreseeable future.

2 
Although the cadastre system now covers the quality of soil and availability of water and mineral 
content, it is far from adequate to meet these expectations, as real property registration remains 
incomplete. The state land cadastre system requires systematic and comprehensive updating to 
cover buildings and property use rights for privatized land. The implications of granting limited 
land use rights for the productivity of privatized farms must be assessed as well. 
 
5.  At the moment, the state land cadastre system is managed and updated by many different 
agencies and therefore lacks consistency in data format and integrity. There is no systematic 
procedure  for  registering  privately  used  farmlands  in  a  unified  cadastre  system,  and  no 
mechanism for efficient land administration and information sharing between the central and local 
governments. The Government recognizes that a rationalized and unified state cadastre system 
is a priority condition for efficient land management and a successful transition toward a market 
economy4 (Cabinet Resolution No. 255, 17 July 1996). It has therefore sought ADB’s assistance 
in developing a methodology for a computerized and integrated land information, property right 
registration, and cadastre system, which can be expanded nationwide. 
 
6.  The Government has received assistance in this regard from international agencies. Staff 
members of the relevant government offices have been trained overseas (under the auspices of 
the Swedish International Development Agency [Sida]). A draft legal framework for a unified 
cadastre system has been developed (Deutsche Gesellschaft fur Technische Zusammenarbeit 
[GTZ]). A feasibility study of a state investment program for establishing a national real property 
rights  registration  system  has  been  carried  out  (European  Union-Technical  Assistance  to 
Commonwealth Independent States [EU-TACIS] Phases I and II, 1996–2002). The proposed TA 
will complement the efforts of these other contributors5 by building on the existing system and 
integrating the necessary elements step by step. 
 
7.  The TA is in line with ADB’s Country Operational Strategy for Uzbekistan and the Country 
Strategy  and  Program  Update.  Both  documents  emphasize  the  importance  of  policy  and 
investment interventions in improving land and water resources management and supporting 
gradual reform in the agriculture sector to increase economic efficiency. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
8.  The long-term sector goal of the TA is to sustain growth in the agriculture sector through 
farm privatization and environmental management. The immediate objective is to assist the 
Government in improving its cadastre system and establishing an integrated mechanism for 
monitoring land use and productivity and for registering property use rights. The computerized 
system will be tested in a designated district in Syrdarya Province where a cooperative farm is 
being reorganized for individual distribution. The system will include all types of information on

5
  Assistance by (i) Sida: Masters of Science in Land Management, since 1998 on a continuing basis for training high-

3 
property, including land use rights and rural and urban building structures, while establishing 
efficient  intergovernmental  coordination.  The  TA  will  have  the  following  outputs:  (i)  a  cost-
effective and transparent methodology for cadastral surveys of agricultural land; (ii) a system of 
land  registration,  including  the  registration  of  buildings,  structures,  and  rural  land;  (iii)  a 
mechanism  for  land  use  and  environment  monitoring;  and  (iv) recommended  legislative 
amendments  to  make  the  cadastral  and  land  registration  procedures  more  transparent  and 
efficient, and to improve security of land tenure for individual farmers. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
9.  The TA has four major components:  
 
(i)  Component  1:  Developing  a  cost-effective  and  transparent  methodology  for 
cadastral surveys of rural land. Cadastral surveys of agricultural land are now based on 
isolated surveys of individual farms without geodetic controls, making it impossible to 
integrate the geographic information into one land information system. Modern technology 
for cadastral surveying would speed up such work and improve its quality by minimizing 
manual errors. The needed information could be compiled from relevant agencies and 
combined into one digital cadastral base map for the area, for various types of analysis 
and applications. Standards and regulations for digital cadastral surveys and mapping will 
be reviewed, and necessary revisions will be suggested, discussed, and adopted. A 
modern “total station” with a data log will be installed at a provincial office, together with 
mapmaking software. Staff will be trained in the methodology, which will be tested in an 
ongoing land redistribution project in the area. The pilot test will be evaluated and a final 
proposal for nationwide implementation will be prepared. 
 
(ii)  Component 2: Developing a complementary registration system for both land and 
building  structures.  The  existing  cadastre  system  should  be  developed  further  to 
accommodate the registration of all land and buildings in one integrated system, while 
keeping the present organizational arrangements for registration. Since this integrated 
system should also be able to handle environmental monitoring, an object-based system 
that can incorporate different work flows will be developed. The graphical and textual 
databases will be integrated. The system design activity should start with assessing (a) 
existing  standards;  (b)  information  and  database  models;  (c)  procedures  of  involved 
agencies; and (d) work flows between the central, provincial, and local governments. At 
least three workstations and additional software need to be installed in one provincial 
office. The system will be developed, tested, and evaluated, and staff will be trained to 
use it. The output will be a proposal for its nationwide application. 
 
(iii)  Component 3: Developing a multipurpose land information system for land use and 
environmental  monitoring.  The  land  registration  system  will  be  developed  into  a 
multipurpose land information system, to improve land management activities in general, 
including cooperative farm restructuring, land use planning, environmental monitoring, 
land valuation, and taxation. This component will focus on the functions of the State 
Committee of Land Resources at the central, provincial, and local levels, and will assess 
the information needed to monitor land use and the environment in relation to private 
farms.  The  required  information  will  be  included  in  the  system  to  be  developed  in 
component 2. Component 3 will pilot-test the system to show how it can be used to 
estimate fairer and more reasonable cotton production quotas and land tax for different 
private  farms.  An  additional  workstation  with  geographic  information  system  (GIS)

4 
software will be installed for this purpose and relevant staff will be trained in data entry 
and the use of environmental information for the pilot project. 
 
(iv)  Component 4: Recommending legislative amendments to make the cadastral and 
land registration procedures more transparent and to strengthen security of tenure. 
The land use rights granted to private farmers still do not include transfer and collateral 
rights.  The  possibility  of  expanding  land  use  rights  and  the  implications  of  such  an 
expansion for agricultural productivity must be further assessed. The cadastral survey 
methodology and integrated land registration system to be developed will eventually also 
streamline land distribution procedures nationwide. Component 4 will therefore focus on 
recommended changes in legislation to this end, based on experiences gained from the 
pilot project and other privatization projects. The draft recommendations will be discussed 
at  a  regional  seminar,  and  the  final  recommendations  will  be  submitted  to  higher 
authorities for consideration.  
 
10.  This TA assumes that development toward a market economy, including the privatization 
of  agricultural  land,  will  continue.  While  its  success  will  be  measured  by  the  nationwide 
application of the integrated land information system, project implementation will depend to a 
large  extent  on  the  commitment  of  the  involved  agencies  to  cooperate  in  developing  and 
implementing the system. The Law on State Cadastres (2000) and the Law on State Land 
Cadastre (1998) have set the preconditions for this cooperation and the TA is well in line with 
these regulations. The involved agencies have committed themselves to cooperating and taking 
ownership  of  the  methodology  to  be  developed  with  the  support  of  the  TA.  Should  the 
Government  decide  on  more  far-reaching  organizational  reforms,  the  integrated  information 
system developed under this TA will be even easier to implement.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $720,000 equivalent, comprising about $417,000 
in foreign exchange and $303,000 equivalent in local currency costs. ADB will provide $500,000 
equivalent  to  finance  the  entire  foreign  exchange  cost  and  $83,000  equivalent  of  the  local 
currency cost on a grant basis from the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. 
The Government will fund the remaining $220,000 equivalent for office accommodation, utilities, 
local  communications,  administrative  support,  and  counterpart  staff.  A  schedule  of  the  cost 
estimates and the financing plan is in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  The  Executing  Agency  (EA)  will  be  the  State  Committee  for  Land  Resources 
(GosKomZem). The EA will form a TA management unit (TAMU), which will include a central task 
force to be responsible for system development work and TA implementation. The TAMU will be 
headed by a qualified full-time project manager and will have secretarial and administrative 
support. The task force will have at least two suitable full-time experts in cadastral surveying, land 
registration, land information systems, and land use and environmental monitoring from both 
GosKomZem  and  the  Main  Administration  of  Geodesy,  Cartography,  and  State  Cadastre 
(UzGeodesCadastre). This task force will be responsible for components 1–4, with support from 
the international technical advisers. The TAMU and task force members should have relevant 
experience and adequate language skills. The province and district selected for the pilot test will 
provide office space and staff for the pilot test—at least four staff members from the province and 
two from the district. The provincial and district staff will be trained in the systems and will 
undertake a cadastral survey and land registration in the pilot test.

5 
13.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  through  close  collaboration  between  the  organizations 
responsible for the state land cadastre system (GosKomZem and UzGeodesCadastre) and for 
building registration (among them, the Bureau of Technical Inventory under UzGeodesCadastre). 
A Steering Committee, with representatives from GosKomZem, UzGeodesCadastre at the central 
level, the provincial government, and the Bureau of Technical Inventory at the provincial level, 
and the local government in the pilot project district, will be formed. It will be chaired by an 
authorized representative from the Cabinet of Ministers, nominated by the Deputy Prime Minister. 
The proposed pilot test area is Syrdarja Province, where cotton and wheat collectives are being 
privatized, and where issues regarding the economic conditions for production, rehabilitation and 
maintenance  of  the  irrigation  system,  land  use,  and  environmental  monitoring  to  reduce 
deteriorating soil quality can be considered during TA implementation. The pilot district, to be 
selected during the inception phase, will be one that has ongoing farm reorganization and that is 
interested in participating in the pilot project. 
 
14.  The TA will require 27 person-months of consulting services (15 international and 12 
domestic). International consultants will give technical advice to the task force in the development 
work and the pilot test. The international consultants will be selected and engaged by ADB 
through a consulting firm in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for the Use of Consultants and 
using the quality- and cost-based selection method. Consultants will submit simplified technical 
proposals. The international consultants will have experts in land administration, system analysis 
and  design,  and  cadastral  surveying.  The  domestic  consultants  who  will  develop  the 
computerized system will be hired from a local information technology consulting firm. They will 
be selected at the system development phase, in accordance with procedures acceptable to 
ADB, through a review of their qualifications for system development using the procured software. 
The  consultants  shall  procure  all  equipment  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  for 
Procurement. Outline terms of reference for consulting services are in Appendix 3. 
 
15.  The TA will be implemented over 12 months from November 2003 and will be completed 
by December 2004. The consultants will submit an inception report, including a detailed work 
plan, within the first month. A progress report will be submitted every 3 months after each of 
these phases: (i) investigations and design, (ii) development and installation, (iii) pilot testing, and 
(iv) evaluation of the pilot test. A draft final report will be prepared and submitted after the 11th 
month, comments from ADB and the EA on the draft will be received within 3 weeks after its 
submission, and the final version of the report, incorporating the comments, will be delivered 
within 1 month after the TA is completed. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Uzbekistan for Developing an Integrated Cadastre System for Land Resources 
Management and Property Right Registration, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTING SERVICES 
 
A.  Overall Arrangements 
 
1.  The consultant will provide advisory support to develop a methodology for an efficient 
and integrated land administration system to be implemented nationwide in the Republic of 
Uzbekistan. The integrated land administration system should build on the existing systems in 
Uzbekistan, using a pilot test approach in a selected district of Syrdarya Province. The advisory 
support will be provided by actively working together with a task force under the Technical 
Assistance Management Unit (TAMU), formed by experts from the State Committee for Land 
Resources  (GosKomZem).  The  Main  Administration  of  Geodesy,  Cartography,  and  State 
Cadastre (UzGeodesCadastre) and other institutions of the central Government will provide 
relevant complementary experts to form a task force under the TAMU. Active interaction is also 
required with the regional and local administration. The consultants will support the TAMU in 
managing TA implementation as well. The consultant will organize and participate in training 
local staff at UzGeodesCadastre and GosKomZem, and also provide on-the-job training to the 
staff at the regional and district offices. The consultant will support activities to improve the land 
users’ understanding and knowledge of the services that the land administration system will 
deliver.  
 
2.  The consultant team leader will report to the TA Steering Committee on the progress of 
the  advisory  services.  The  consultant  will  engage  the  domestic  consultants  from  a  local 
computer information technology consultancy firm and will procure hardware and software. 
Selection will be through a procedure acceptable for Asian Development Bank (ADB). The TA 
will be implemented during 12 months. 
 
B.  Scope of Work 
 
3.  The TA is expected to develop the following and deliver the necessary outputs: 
 
(i)  a cost-effective and transparent methodology for cadastral surveys of rural land 
developed, 
(ii)  a complemented registration system for both buildings and rural land plots, 
(iii)  a multipurpose land information system needed for monitoring land use and the 
environment, 
(iv)  proposals for amending legislation to improve the transparency and efficiency of 
the cadastral and land registration procedures and to strengthen the security of 
tenure for land users elaborated; and 
(v)  an investigation of the preconditions for financing the nationwide implementation 
of the developed system through an ADB loan. This investigation will be included 
in the final report of the consultant. 
 
4.  The TA will comprise four distinct phases: 
 
(i)  Investigate the current situation and design a cadastral methodology and an 
integrated land administration system; 
(ii)  Procure and install equipment, construct a test system, and train staff at the 
provincial offices in Syrdarya region; 
(iii)  Pilot-test  the  systems  in  one  district  in  the  province  within  an  ongoing  land 
reorganization project; and

(iv)  Evaluate  the  pilot  test  and  elaborate  a  final  proposal  for  countrywide 
implementation. Elaborate proposals for legislative amendments to (a) achieve 
cost-efficient procedures for cadastral surveying and land registration, and (b) 
improve the land tenure security for individual farmers. 
 
5.  The consultant will support the TAMU to carry out the following, among others: 
 
(i)  Investigate and analyze the current situation and possibilities, 
(ii)  Design and develop methodology and additional functions to the land registration 
system, 
(iii)  Design and develop functionality for land use and environmental control, 
(iv)  Organize workshops to discuss and disseminate possible solutions, 
(v)  Procure hardware and software for the pilot test, 
(vi)  Engage  domestic  consultants  for  construction  of  the  system  including 
customization of software, 
(vii)  Establish the regional pilot test office and train staff, 
(viii)  Perform the pilot test, 
(ix)  Evaluate the pilot test and the need to amend legislation, 
(x)  Elaborate proposals for legislative amendment, 
(xi)  Investigate land users’ satisfaction with the system, 
(xii)  Organize a regional seminar, 
(xiii)  Prepare an inception report, 
(xiv)  Prepare progress reports every 3 months, and 
(xv)  Prepare the final report. 
 
C.  International Consultant Team 
 
6.  The  consultancy  team  (person-months  in  parentheses)  will  comprise  (i)  land 
administration expert and team leader (9); (ii) cadastral surveying and mapping expert (1.5); and 
(iii) system analyst and database design expert (4.5). The international consultancy should not 
exceed 15 person-months. The consultancy team is expected to engage domestic consultants 
up to about 12 person-months during the inception stage for system construction. The domestic 
consultants should be familiar with programming in the software system that will be procured for 
the TA. Further details of the terms of reference for each international expert are as follows. 
 
1.  Land Administration Expert/Team Leader (9 person-months) 
 
7.  The land administration expert will advise on the general design of the integrated land 
administration system and on procedures for integrated land administration between involved

3.  System Analyst and Database Design Expert (4.5 person-months) 
 
11.  The  system  analyst  and  data  base  design  expert  will  advise  on  the  design  of  the

expert will also advise on engaging domestic consultants, assist in system construction, and 
participate in training users of the system. The expert should have a relevant university degree 
in system analysis, database development, or other relevant information technology (IT) topics. 
More than 10 years of work experience in developing IT systems for land administration is 
required. Further, (i) experience in system analysis and database design for land information

experience in working in IT development in transitional and developing countries are required.

(ii)  Analyze the need for cadastral information by GosKomZem and potential users 
of an integrated land registration system; 
(iii)  Advise  on  expanding  the  information  model  and  the  database  model  to

D.  Domestic Consultants Team for System Construction and Programming (3 persons 
for 4 months) 
 
13.  The domestic consultants will be engaged for constructing the system designed by the 
TA task force with experts’ inputs from the system analyst and database design expert. The 
system will be based on already existing software for land registration, which will be expanded 
with information on rural land, all types of buildings and constructions, and data for land use and 
environmental  control.  For  graphic  information,  a  software  package  will  be  procured  (by 
international consultants), which also is functional for GIS applications. The types of applications 
will be elaborated during the design phase. The domestic consultants will be engaged after the 
design phase to procure hardware and software. The construction phase is estimated to take
